questions.text: A new vaccine has been developed to target the 23 serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae. This polysaccharide vaccine promises to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with pneumococcal infections, particularly in certain high-risk groups. Which of the following patient groups would most likely derive the most benefit from this vaccine? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A patient with sickle cell disease 

 

  • The polysaccharide vaccine targeting Streptococcus pneumoniae (PPSV-23) provides the greatest advantages to individuals with sickle cell disease.
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is a bacteria enveloped in a protective layer that the spleen recognizes and eliminates.
  • However, in the case of sickle cell disease, the distorted shape of red blood cells obstructs the spleen's blood vessels, leading to damage.
  • This compromised spleen function, known as hyposplenism, raises the susceptibility to pneumococcal infections.
  • Consequently, sickle cell patients receive the pneumococcal vaccine (PPSV-23) as a preventive measure, aimed at diminishing this vulnerability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A child < 2 years: Polysaccharide vaccines are not effective in children under 2 years old due to their immature immune systems. Conjugate vaccines are preferred for this age group.

 

Option C. A patient with cystic fibrosis: While at risk for lung infections, cystic fibrosis patients benefit more from vaccines targeting typical respiratory pathogens, and their spleen function is usually normal.

 

Option D. A patient with recurrent otitis media: This condition is typically managed with other interventions, and the need for a polysaccharide vaccine is less critical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The PPSV-23 vaccine is most beneficial for patients with sickle cell disease due to their increased susceptibility to pneumococcal infections caused by compromised spleen function.

questions.text: A 38-year-old civil engineer is working on a construction project in an area recently affected by a devastating earthquake. To prevent future devastation, the local government has amended the building codes. These changes are aimed at ensuring structures in the area can better withstand seismic activity. The engineer reviews the changes to determine the best approach for the new construction project. This modification to the building codes is primarily an example of which phase of disaster management? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Disaster mitigation

 

  • The measures that are taken to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are part of disaster mitigation.
  • Mitigation involves measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing an emergency or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. In most cases mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system.

 

In Disaster Cycle, the steps involved are –

 

  1. Disaster Impact and Response: it involves search, rescue, first aid of the patients, triaging them according to the severity of their injuries and their likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention, tagging and identification of dead.
  2. Relief Phase or Disaster Containment by prompt assistance, epidemiological surveillance and disease control, vaccination, nutritional support.
  3. Rehabilitation involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions. It takes into account assessment and restoration of water supply, food safety and supply, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, vector control.
  4. Disaster Mitigation involves measures aimed at reducing or preventing the hazards from causing any emergency or to dampen the effects of emergencies. It involves flood mitigation works, appropriate land-use planning, improved building codes and reduction or protection of vulnerable population and structures.
  5. Disaster Preparedness is a long-term programme of developmental activities which aims at strengthening the overall capacity and capability of the country to efficiently and effectively manage all the emergencies.  

 

   

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disaster mitigation involves proactive measures such as improved building codes to reduce the impact of future disasters, aiming to lessen vulnerability and enhance resilience against potential hazards.

questions.text: A genetic counsellor is discussing various types of genetic tests with a couple planning for a child. Which of the following statements accurately describes genetic screening? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder

 

Genetic screening/testing

 

  • Genetic testing is a type of medical test that identifies changes in genes, chromosomes, or proteins. 
  • It is a process to analyse blood or skin for the systematic search for persons with a particular genotype in a defined population (usually invasive procedures)
  • In order to locate this faulty gene, scientists search for variations in larger pieces of DNA called "markers", latter are found nearby the DNA and become the basis of genetic screening
  • The results of a genetic test can confirm or rule out a suspected genetic condition or help determine a person's chance of developing or passing on a genetic. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests: Incorrect. Screening tests assess risk and are not as definitive as diagnostic tests, which provide a precise diagnosis.

 

Option C. Screening requires genetic mapping: Incorrect. Genetic screening does not necessarily involve genetic mapping, which is a detailed analysis of the entire genome.

 

Option D. Involve invasive procedures: Incorrect. Screening tests can often be performed using non-invasive methods such as blood or saliva samples, although some genetic tests may require invasive procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genetic screening tests are used to define the risk of passing on a genetic disorder and can help determine the likelihood of developing a genetic condition.
  • They are not as definitive as diagnostic tests and do not necessarily involve invasive procedures or genetic mapping.

questions.text: What percentage of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 68%

 

Approximately 68% of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve.

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD à Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD à Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD à Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Approximately 68% of the data in a normal distribution lies within one standard deviation (±1σ) from the mean.

questions.text: You are a public health researcher evaluating a new screening test for early detection of a specific disease in a community. Your team successfully conducted a pilot study in a small group. Before planning a large-scale implementation, you wish to ensure that the findings from your pilot study can be applied to larger, diverse groups of individuals outside your initial sample. This ability to extrapolate the findings in the broader population, i.e. the external validity of a screening test is related to which of the following options? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Generalizability

 

  • Generalizability refers to the extent to which the findings from a study or pilot test can be applied to a broader population.
  • It is a measure of the external validity of a study.
  • Ensuring that the results of a pilot study can be extrapolated to larger, diverse groups outside the initial sample is crucial for the success of large-scale implementations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stability: Refers to the consistency of test results over time, ensuring that repeated measurements yield the same results under unchanged conditions. While important, it does not address how findings apply to different populations.

 

Option B. Objectivity: Ensures that test results are unbiased and not influenced by the person administering the test. While critical for reliable results, it does not relate to applying findings to a broader population.

 

Option D. Repeatability: Refers to the consistency of the test results when repeated under identical conditions. This is crucial for reliability but does not address the applicability of the results to different populations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External validity of a screening test is related to generalizability.

 

Validity refers to what extent the test measures which it purports to measure (adequacy of measurement).

 

Types of Validity

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man has been diagnosed with tuberculosis. As part of his treatment plan, he is prescribed a combination of antitubercular drugs. While counseling him on the drug regimen, you explain the mechanisms of action of each drug. Which of the following combinations of statements accurately describe the mechanisms of some of the drugs used in treating tuberculosis? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis
  2. Pyrazinamide is an enzyme inducer
  3. Rifampicin is used only in the treatment of tuberculosis
  4. Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 4

 

1. lsoniazid - INH is activated by catalase peroxidase (formed by Kat G) enzyme of mycobacteria. It acts by inhibiting the formation of mycolic acid.

 

4. Bedaquiline - Act by inhibiting ATP synthase enzyme, can result in QT prolongation

 

Other Options:

 

2. Pyrazinamide - Possess the best sterilizing activity (can kill slow growing bacteria) and makes the medium sterile. Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is not an enzyme inducer.

 

3. Rifampicin - Act by inhibiting RNA polymerase of mycobacteria by binding to its β-subunit. It thus inhibits transcription. Uses of Rifampicin are:

 

  • Tuberculosis
  • Leprosy
  • DOC for Brucella (doxycycline + rifampicin)
  • Effective against Gram positive bacteria (including MRSA)
  • Effective against Gram negative bacteria (including Pseudomonas)
  • It was used for prophylaxis of meningococcus meningitis

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis.
  • Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase enzyme.
  • Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation
  • Rifampicin inhibit RNA polymerase

Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A new combined treatment regimen of chemotherapy and immunotherapy has significantly increased survival in patients with metastatic melanoma. If the number of new cases remains consistent, but patients live longer, which epidemiological impact would be observed? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

  • Due to the new drug combination, patient survival rates have risen, resulting in a situation where the incidence remains unchanged while prevalence sees an increase.

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

 

Since New cases will keep on occurring at the same rate, Incidence will remain same. Duration will increase (as survival increases). So, overall Prevalence will increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When patient survival increases due to a new treatment, the incidence of the disease remains the same, but the prevalence increases due to longer survival duration.

The image shows a sling psychrometer, which is an instrument used to measure the water content, moisture content, or air humidity.

The sling psychrometer is an instrument used to measure air humidity by comparing the temperatures of a wet bulb and a dry bulb thermometer.

She comes across several vaccine vials, each with a Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) attached. The VVMs change color to indicate the cumulative exposure of the vaccine to heat, thus helping in determining the viability of the vaccine. She notices varying degrees of color changes across these VVMs. Given this scenario, which of the following choices correctly identifies which vaccine vials, based on the observed VVM color changes, should be considered safe for use? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

  • Based on the image provided, it's evident that only vials 1 and 2 are suitable for use because the inner squares of these vials color lighter than the outer circles.

  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.

questions.text: Mineral deficiency clinically found to be associated with sexual dysfunction is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Zinc

 

Zinc deficiency is well-documented to be associated with several reproductive and sexual health issues. It is particularly known for causing Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, a rare genetic disorder.

 

Zinc deficiency can lead to sexual infantilism, sterility, diarrhea, brittle nails, loss of taste, growth failure, etc. Additionally, zinc is crucial for maintaining healthy testosterone levels, which is vital for sexual health in both men and women.

 

In pregnancy, zinc deficiency can result in low birth weight, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), congenital malformations, and even spontaneous abortions, further highlighting its critical role in reproductive health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molybdenum: Molybdenum deficiency is associated with conditions such as mouth or esophageal cancer and respiratory and neurological issues. There is no direct link between molybdenum deficiency and sexual dysfunction.

 

Option B. Copper: Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, bone fractures, neutropenia, osteoporosis, depigmentation of the skin, and thyroid issues. However, it is not linked to sexual dysfunction.

 

Option D. Magnesium: Magnesium deficiency is primarily associated with irritability, tetany, hyperreflexia, and impaired metabolism of potassium and calcium. It does not have a direct connection with sexual dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sexual dysfunction occur due to deficiency of Zinc, calcium, Vitamin D and B12. Essential fatty acid deficiency may also be associated with sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: Which article in the Indian Constitution grants the Right to Life to the individuals of India? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Article 21 

 

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the Right to Life and personal liberty to all its citizens. This article is pivotal as it ensures that no person is deprived of their life or personal liberty except according to the procedure established by law. This right is comprehensive, covering a range of aspects that ensure not just mere survival but a life with dignity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Article 11: Defines the right of the parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law.

 

Option C. Article 23: Defines the prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labor.

 

Option D. Article 25: Defines the freedom of conscience and free profession, practice, and propagation of religion. While it pertains to personal liberties, it specifically addresses religious freedoms and not the general Right to Life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution is critical as it enshrines the Right to Life and personal liberty, ensuring that every individual's life and personal freedoms are protected under the law.

questions.text: An acute encephalitis outbreak has occurred within the community, prompting the initiation of a vaccination campaign. Which of the following is true about the vaccine given in this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Killed and intramuscular

 

Explanation:

 

The question is referring to Japanese Encephalitis (JE) outbreaks, which are not uncommon in India and parts of Southeast Asia. During such outbreaks, emergency vaccination campaigns are often undertaken to control the spread of disease.

 

The most commonly used vaccine in these public health campaigns in India earlier used to be Live JE SA 14-14-2 vaccine (subcutaneous). But nowadays, the inactivated (killed) Vero cell–derived JE vaccine - JENVAC is used intramuscularly.

 

Hence, the correct response based on updated national guidelines is:

 

Killed and intramuscular.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Live and subcutaneous:

While the SA 14-14-2 vaccine is a live, attenuated vaccine given subcutaneously, recent protocols for outbreak settings increasingly prefer killed vaccines like JENVAC, especially in adult populations and for mass campaigns due to ease of storage and safety. Live vaccine SA -14-14-2 is quite good during outbreaks too. But JENVAC has an edge over SA 14-14-2 because of the higher immunity levels it creates with a single dose. Hence, although previously correct, SA 14-14-2 is no longer the preferred or updated answer.

 

Option C) Live and intramuscular:

Live vaccines (like SA 14-14-2) are given subcutaneously. IM route is not used for Live JE SA 14-14-2 routinely.

 

Option D) Killed and subcutaneous:

Killed JE vaccines (like JENVAC or IXIARO) are administered intramuscularly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of a Japanese Encephalitis outbreak, the vaccine currently recommended and used in mass immunization campaigns in India is a killed (inactivated) vaccine administered via the intramuscular route, such as JENVAC. While older guidelines or some regions may have used the live attenuated SA 14-14-2 vaccine given subcutaneously, updated practices now favor the inactivated IM vaccine due to its broader safety profile and compatibility with adult vaccination. Always refer to the most recent national immunization guidelines when answering such public health–related MCQs.

questions.text: You are a nutritionist giving a lecture about milk pasteurization and its quality assurance tests. A curious student inquires about the various tests to validate the efficacy of pasteurization. You begin to list them, but highlight one that is not directly related to the pasteurization process. Which of the following tests does not directly evaluate the efficiency of milk pasteurization? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) lodine test 

 

  • Given tests are associated with the milk pasteurization process except for the iodine test.
  • This test is conducted to examine the potential adulteration of milk with starch or cereal flour.
  • Iodine test - The presence of addition of starch in milk can be detected using an iodine test.
  • When two or three drops of iodine solution is added to milk taken in a test tube, the solution turns dark blue.
  • This shows the presence of starch mixed with the milk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphatase Test: Used to check for the presence of the enzyme phosphatase, which should be inactivated by proper pasteurization. This ensures that the milk has been heated sufficiently.

 

Option C. Standard Plate Count: Measures the total bacterial count to ensure it meets the standards for pasteurized milk. A lower count indicates effective pasteurization.

 

Option D. Methylene Blue Reduction Test: Measures the time it takes for methylene blue to lose its color, which correlates with bacterial activity; high counts indicate inadequate pasteurization. This test helps verify the reduction of microbial load.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PASTEURIZATION TESTS:

 

  1. Phosphatase Test: Widely used test
  2. Standard Plate Count: Standard is coliforms be absent in 1 ml of milk
  3. Methylene blue reduction test: Enforced limit is 30,000 bacterial count per ml of pasteurized milk

questions.text: Sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipette is: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Autoclaving and 70% ethanol

 

The most effective sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipettes, as indicated by the available methods, is autoclaving in combination with 70% ethanol.

 

Autoclaving is a reliable method of sterilization that involves exposing the material to high temperature and pressure (121°C at 15 psi) for a specific period, typically 20 minutes. This method effectively kills bacteria, viruses, and spores.

 

Chemical disinfectants

 

 

So, 70% ethanol is widely used as a disinfectant due to its ability to denature proteins and dissolve lipids, making it highly effective at eliminating microbial contamination on glass surfaces.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microwaving and 95% ethanol: Microwaving is not a standard sterilization method for glass pipettes. Although 95% ethanol can be used for disinfection, it is less effective than 70% ethanol because it evaporates too quickly to kill all microbes thoroughly.

 

Option B. Autoclaving: While autoclaving alone is an effective sterilization method, the question specifies the tip of disposable glass pipettes, where combining it with 70% ethanol enhances the sterilization process.

 

Option D. Hot air oven: A hot air oven can be used for sterilization, but it requires longer exposure times at higher temperatures. This method is less efficient compared to autoclaving combined with ethanol, especially for small, delicate items like pipette tips.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipettes is autoclaving combined with 70% ethanol. Autoclaving provides high heat and pressure to eliminate microorganisms, while 70% ethanol ensures thorough disinfection.

questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Vaccine vial monitor

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.
  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.
  • Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.
  • If the square and the circle are the same in colour or square is darker, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. e-VIN: e-VIN (Electronic Vaccine Intelligence Network) tracks the stock status and temperature of vaccine inventories via the internet, but it does not assess the viability of individual vaccine vials upon arrival.

 

Option B. Freeze indicator: Freeze indicator detects exposure to freezing temperatures, which can damage vaccines, but it does not indicate heat exposure.

 

Option D. Fridge indicator: Fridge indicator monitors the temperature inside a refrigerator, ensuring it remains within a safe range but does not provide specific information about the exposure of individual vaccine vials during transport.

questions.text: As part of a health development project in rural India, you're asked about the key community group responsible for overseeing local health, sanitation, and nutrition initiatives. Which committee best fits this description? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee

 

  • One of the key elements of the National Rural Health Mission is the Village Health, Sanitation and Nutrition committee (VHSNC).
  • The committee has been formed to take collective actions on issues related to health and its social determinants at the village level.
  • They are particularly envisaged as being central to ‘local level community action’ under NRHM, which would develop to support the process of Decentralized Health Planning.
  • Thus VHSNC is envisaged to take leadership in providing a platform for improving health awareness and access of community for health services, address specific local needs and serve as a mechanism for community based planning and monitoring.
  • The committee is formed at the revenue village level and it should act as a sub-committee of the Gram Panchayat.
  • It should have a minimum of 15 members which should comprise of elected member of the Panchayat who shall lead the committee, all those working for health and health related services should participate, community members/ beneficiaries and representation from all community sub-groups especially the vulnerable sections and hamlets/ habitations. ASHA residing in the village shall be the member secretary and convener of the committee.

 

 ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES 

 

  • Create awareness about nutritional issues and significance of nutrition as an important determinant of health.
  • Carry out survey on nutritional status and nutritional deficiencies in the village especially among women and children.
  • Identify locally available food stuffs of high nutrient value as well as disseminate and promote best practices (traditional wisdom) congruent with local culture, capabilities and physical environment through a process of community consultation.
  • Inclusion of Nutritional needs in the Village Health Plan – The committee will do an in-depth analysis of causes of malnutrition at the community and household levels, by involving the ANM, AWW, ASHA and ICDS Supervisors.
  • Monitoring and Supervision of Village Health and Nutrition Day to ensure that it is organized every month in the village with the active participation of the whole village.
  • Facilitate early detection of malnourished children in the community; tie up referral to the nearest Nutritional Rehabilitation Centre (NRC) as well as follow up for sustained outcome.
  • Supervise the functioning of Anganwadi Centre (AWC) in the village and facilitate its working in improving nutritional status of women and children.
  • Act as a grievances redressal forum on health and nutrition issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Panchayat Health Committee and Option B. Village Health Planning and Management Committee generally refer to broader terms, but they do not specifically target the integrated approach of the VHSNC.

 

Option C. Rogi Kalyan Samiti (Patient Welfare Committee) / Hospital Management Committee is a simple yet effective management structure. This committee, a registered society, acts as a group of trustees for the hospitals to manage the affairs of the hospital. It consists of members from local Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs), NGOs, local elected representatives and officials from Government sector who are responsible for proper functioning and management of the hospital / Community Health Centre / FRUs. RKS / HMS is free to prescribe, generate and use the funds with it as per its best judgement for smooth functioning and maintaining the quality of services.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The VHSNC plays a crucial role in the grassroots-level health planning and implementation in rural India, ensuring that health initiatives are tailored to the specific needs and conditions of the community.
  • It is a vital part of the health ecosystem, facilitating a comprehensive approach to public health management in rural settings.

questions.text: Which vector is responsible for transmitting Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mites.

 

Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi is the causative agent of scrub typhus, a type of rickettsial disease. The primary vector responsible for transmitting Rickettsia Tsutsugamushi is the trombiculid mite, commonly known as a chigger. These mites are parasitic larvae that bite humans and other animals, transmitting the bacteria through their saliva during feeding.

 

Scrub typhus is prevalent in areas with dense scrub vegetation, hence the name. Rodents often serve as the reservoir hosts for the bacteria, maintaining the infection cycle in nature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Louse: Lice are vectors for other rickettsial diseases, such as epidemic typhus (Rickettsia prowazekii), but not for scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Flea: Fleas are vectors for diseases like murine typhus (Rickettsia typhi) but are not involved in the transmission of scrub typhus.

questions.text:
A team of researchers is conducting investigations to evaluate the impact of interventions targeting a specific disease. Two independent studies, labeled as A and B, are analyzed. Study A utilized an intervention denoted as "X", and Study B utilized an intervention denoted as "Y". Both studies incorporate control groups. The calculated p-values for studies A and B, with 95% confidence intervals, were found to be 0.02 and 0.001, respectively.  Based on this information, which of the following conclusions is most appropriate? [AIIMS MAY 2019]

 

  1. Study B is more precise than study A and intervention Y is more significant compared to Intervention X.
  2. Study A is more precise than study B and intervention X is more significant compared to Intervention Y.
  3. Both X and Y show a significant variation, but Study B is more significant than Study A.
  4. Both study A and B show a significant variation and both interventions have similar statistical significance.
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) If 1 and 3 are correct

 

  • Statements 1 and 3 are accurate. The p-value for study A involving intervention X within a 95% confidence interval stands at 0.02.
  • In the case of study B, employing intervention Y within the same confidence interval, the p-value is 0.001.
  • Both studies' probability (p) values fall below the 0.05 threshold (level of significance - α), leading to the conclusion that both studies A and B hold significance and thus warrant the rejection of the null hypothesis.
  • Nevertheless, study B exhibits a p-value lower than that of study A, implying that the precision and significance of study B, involving intervention Y, surpass those of study A with intervention X.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 2: This is incorrect as it mistakenly asserts that Study A, which had a higher p-value, would be more precise and that intervention X would be more significant than intervention Y. This is opposite to what the p-values suggest.

 

Option 4: Also incorrect because it suggests that both interventions have similar statistical significance, which contradicts the considerable difference in their p-values. A lower p-value in Study B indicates a stronger statistical significance compared to Study A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In interpreting clinical study results, a lower p-value indicates stronger evidence against the null hypothesis and typically points to a more significant intervention effect.
  • In this scenario, Study B's intervention (Y) is statistically more significant than Study A's intervention (X), indicating a potentially more effective or impactful intervention.

questions.text: Dr. Sharma was enthusiastically reviewing the results of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aimed to compare the therapeutic benefits of Drug A and Drug B. To her surprise, the data suggested a statistically significant difference between the two medications, indicated by a p-value of <0.005. However, after a comprehensive review and collaboration with other experts, it was established that in real-world settings, both drugs had essentially equivalent therapeutic outcomes. This error in interpretation, where a difference was falsely identified when none existed in reality, is best described by which of the following statistical terms? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Alpha error

 

  • In the given scenario, null hypothesis (H0) can be that the two drugs being the same in effectiveness is true in reality.
  • The alternative hypothesis will be that both drugs are different.
  • Since P-value was found to be < 0.005, means that data is statistically significant and thus, null hypothesis is rejected.
  • But it is already established that the null hypothesis is true and now if we accept the alternative hypothesis even though it is false, this will be a type I error or alpha error.
  • Hypothesis (H): Is an assumption about the status of a phenomenon
  • Null Hypothesis (H0): In Biostatistics, when we have to prove a particular hypothesis about difference between 2 regimens, we make Null Hypothesis (For examples, If we have to prove that new treatment is better than older treatment, H0 = new treatment is not better than older treatment).

 

Statistical errors:

 

 

Type I Error (Alpha Error):

 

  • Null hypothesis is true but rejected
  • Probability of Type I error is given by ‘P – value’ (probability of declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present)
  • Significance (a) level: is the maximum tolerable probability of Type I error
  • Alpha is fixed in advance: P – value calculated can be less than, equal to or greater than alpha (a)
  • Keep Type I error to be minimum (P < a): Then results are declared statistically significant

 

Type II Error (Beta Error):

 

  • Null hypothesis is false but not rejected (or accepted)
  • Probability of Type II error is given by beta (b) (probability of declaring no significant difference when actually it is present)

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has developed white patches on his anterior incisors, which have recently turned brown. His mother is concerned about the cause. Which element is most likely responsible for this discoloration? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fluorine

 

Dental fluorosis occurs when excess fluoride is ingested during first 7 years of life (years of tooth calcification). It occurs at levels above 1.5 mg/litre intake. It is characterized by ’Mottling’, which is best seen on incisors of upper jaw. 

 

Definition of Suspect case of Dental Fluorosis (in children): Any case with a history of residing in an endemic area along with one or both of the followings:

 

  • Chalky white teeth/white spots on the white enamel surface
  • Transverse yellow, brown/black bands or spots on the enamel surface

 

 

Ideally in water there should be 0.5 to 0.8 mg/l of fluorine (India). The major source of fluorine in human is Drinking water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorine: Chlorine is used for water disinfection and is not associated with dental discoloration.

 

Option C. Iodine: Iodine deficiency can cause goiter and other thyroid-related issues but not dental discoloration.

 

Option D. Iron: Excessive iron can cause dark stains on teeth but does not cause the white to brown transition seen in dental fluorosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dental fluorosis is caused by the ingestion of excess fluoride during the early years of life, leading to characteristic tooth discoloration.

 

Additional Information

 

Fluorine is a double edged sword. 

 

  • Dental Fluorosis occurs when Fluorine level is > 0.8mg/l in water. In that case, the water should be defluoridated using Nalgonda technique. 
  • If the level of fluorine is < 0.5mg/l, then the fluorine deficiency will lead to Dental Caries. In that case, fluorine supplementation should be done.

questions.text: A new diagnostic test for dengue is being evaluated using a Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) graph. As the curve transitions from the green region to the pink region, what is the most likely change in the test characteristics? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Both sensitivity and specificity increase

 

As the curve transitions from green to pink, both sensitivity and specificity experience an increase.

 

  • Sensitivity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease (cases)

 

Sensitivity = a/ (a + c) × 100 = TP/ (TP + FN) × 100

 

  • Specificity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease (healthy)

 

Specificity = d/ (b + d) × 100 = TN/ (TN + FP) × 100

 

 

 

As the curve transitions from green to pink, it increases the count of true positives and negatives while decreases the occurrences of false positives and negatives. Consequently, this shift results in increased sensitivity and specificity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On an ROC graph, a transition from one region to another indicating improved test performance generally means that both sensitivity and specificity are increasing.

questions.text: In a cohort study done in a community, out of those 100 vaccinated for malaria, only 6 developed the disease. At the same time, out of those 100 non-vaccinated, a total of 12 developed the disease. Find the relative risk in the study:  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.5

 

To find the relative risk (RR) in this study, we first need to calculate the incidence of the disease in both the vaccinated (exposed) and non-vaccinated (non-exposed) groups.

 

Step 1: Incidence in the vaccinated group (exposed):

 

  • Number of vaccinated individuals = 100
  • Number of vaccinated individuals who developed the disease = 6
  • Incidence in the vaccinated group = 6/100 = 0.06

 

Step 2: Incidence in the non-vaccinated group (non-exposed):

 

  • Number of non-vaccinated individuals = 100
  • Number of non-vaccinated individuals who developed the disease = 12
  • Incidence in the non-vaccinated group = 12/100 = 0.12

 

Step 3: Calculate Relative Risk (RR):
 

  • RR = Incidence in the exposed group / Incidence in the non-exposed group
  • RR = 0.06 / 0.12 = 0.5

 

The relative risk of 0.5 indicates that the vaccinated individuals were half as likely to develop malaria compared to those who were not vaccinated. This suggests a protective effect of the vaccine against malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a cohort study, the relative risk is calculated by comparing the incidence of the outcome in the exposed group to the incidence in the non-exposed group.

 

A relative risk less than 1 indicates a protective effect of the exposure, as seen in this example where vaccination reduced the risk of malaria.

questions.text: A male patient who was diagnosed with tuberculosis has successfully completed the full course of treatment. Subsequent to finishing both the intensive and continuation phases, the initial sputum examination was conducted. The results of this examination were negative. What is the current condition of the patient? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cured

 

A patient with negative sputum examination at the end of tuberculosis treatment indicates that the patient has been cured of the disease.

 

Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that primarily affects the lungs and causes pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

  • A TB case can be confirmed by positive results on smear microscopy and culture of biological specimens or diagnosed clinically by a clinician who prescribes a full course of TB treatment.
  • TB treatment consists of two phases: the intensive phase lasting for two months and the continuation phase lasting for four months.
  • Treatment involves four drugs in the intensive phase, namely isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, and isoniazid along with rifampicin and ethambutol in the continuation phase.
  • After completion of treatment, the patient's sputum/culture is tested and assigned one of the following outcomes: cured, treatment completed, treatment failed, lost to follow-up, died, or not evaluated, depending on the results of the test and the patient's medical history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Treatment Completed: Refers to a patient who has completed treatment without evidence of failure but lacks documented negative sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion.

 

Option C. Lost to Follow-Up: Refers to a patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for two consecutive months or more.

 

Option D. Treatment Failed: Refers to a patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after 5 months or more of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terminologies:

 

  • Cured - A TB patient whose smear or culture turned negative in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion
  • Treatment completed - A TB patient who completed treatment without any failure, but has no record to show that sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion were negative; it may be either because tests were not done or because results are unavailable
  • Treatment failed - A TB patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after treatment for 5 months or more
  • Lost to follow-up - A TB patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more
  • Died - A TB patient who dies before starting or during the course of treatment for any reason
  • Not evaluated - A TB patient for whom no treatment outcome is assigned; this includes cases "transferred out" to another treatment unit and cases for whom the treatment outcome is unknown to the reporting unit whose treatment is interrupted

They are typically used when the data are not normally distributed, have outliers, or when the sample size is small.

Other Options:

Educational Objective:

 

Non-parametric tests are valuable statistical tools when dealing with skewed distributions or when the assumptions of parametric tests (like normal distribution) are not met. They provide robustness against the distribution shape of the data and are effective in handling smaller sample sizes and outliers.

questions.text: A drug trial was initiated under Medicine department to test the efficacy of a new medication in comparison to a placebo. The participants were divided into two cohorts. Cohort A received a placebo, while cohort B was treated with the novel drug. Out of the 120 participants in cohort A, 36 faced fatal outcomes. In cohort B, with 130 participants, there were 26 fatal outcomes. Given this data, if a clinician were to incorporate this novel medication into practice, how many patients would they need to treat with this new medication to prevent one additional fatality when compared to the placebo group? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 10

 

10 patients need to be treated with the new drug to avert 1 death.

 

We can group divide the case scenario into two groups:

 

Experimental (New treatment) group – 26 Treatment failures out of 130

 

Control (Old treatment) group – 36 Treatment failures out of 120

 

 

Now, we have to calculate failure rate in both groups:

 

Experimental (New treatment) group – 26/130 = 0.2

 

Control (Old treatment) group – 36/120 = 0.3

 

 Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is the difference of failure in both groups = 0.3 – 0.2 = 0.1

 

Number needed to treat (NNT) = 1/ARR = 1/0.1 = 10

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Number Needed to Treat (NNT) is a practical measure used in decision-making for clinical interventions.
  • It represents the number of patients that need to be treated with a particular therapy over a specific period to prevent one additional bad outcome, such as death in this scenario.
  • An NNT of 10 indicates that the new medication has a significant impact in reducing fatalities compared to the placebo.
